Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Frequency Comb Laser Diagnostics for Combustion Environments

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1454496 - Rieker

The principal investigator will develop a measurement technique to be used in combustion environments that are too harsh for traditional sensors. The goal is to achieve a laser light with multiple wavelengths that can simultaneously determine multiple property values (such as temperature and species concentrations) with high resolutions. The knowledge thus gained can be used for enhancing energy efficiency and pollution reduction. It also involves students in hands-on laboratory activities, and training graduate students for advanced research.

The research objective of this CAREER grant is to address the difficulties of in-situ, multi-species, multi-property measurements in combustion environments by establishing the first frequency comb (i.e., consisting of multiple peaks at discrete narrow-band frequencies) laser-based tools and techniques for combustion systems. The frequency comb is capable of broadband absorption sensing with unprecedented spectral resolution and speed. This project will overcome the remaining challenges to practical frequency comb-based sensing in combustion environments, namely reducing system complexity and improving signal-to-noise ratio. The project will demonstrate the technique for multi-species, multi-property (e.g. temperature, pressure, species concentration) measurements in a coal gasification reactor. The project will also enable mid-infrared frequency comb measurements in the C-H stretch spectral region of many hydrocarbons, with the simplicity of in-situ laser absorption spectroscopy as well as the multi-species capabilities of extractive gas chromatography or mass spectroscopy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this project was to enable a new class of in-situ, broadband optical sensors for the combustion community based on Nobel prize winning frequency comb lasers.  The project also intended to strengthen the combustion community through improved undergraduate academic preparation in complex thermal systems, and improved channels toward careers in energy and combustion for high school students, with a priority on under-represented students.

The major goal can be broken into 5 specific goals. (1) Creation of the first portable dual frequency comb spectrometer (DCS), applicable to practical combustion systems. (2) Advancement of DCS technology to enable high signal-to-noise in-situ measurements of multiple high-pressure gas species simultaneously in an entrained flow gasifier, overcoming significant challenges to current measurement systems. (3) Wavelength shifting of the DCS to the mid-infrared where hydrocarbon molecules absorb strongly. (4)  Sensing using the DCS in complex combustion environments. (5)  Development of a new undergraduate thermal systems capstone course, and an extension of the course to a workshop that fosters understanding of energy career paths for high school students.

We have completed and exceeded all five specific goals. We fielded the first portable dual-comb spectrometer and deployed it to sense the exhaust gas parameters of a 16 MW stationary gas turbine.  This was the first fielded dual-comb experiment in any field of research, including combustion.  We improved dual-comb sensor time resolution by 10000x from our previous broadband dual comb measurements and made measurements not just in a coal gasifier but a rapid compression machine that simulates automotive engine combustion.  We developed a new, much simpler approach for mid-IR dual-comb that is on the path to portability. We performed mid-IR dual-comb sensing in a complex wood pyrolysis experiment, detecting multiple hydrocarbon, intermediate, and product species simultaneously. We advanced several research efforts that greatly expanded objective 4 beyond the original scope of the CAREER award.  In particular, we developed an approach to sense non-uniform temperature profiles along the laser line-of-sight, new high temperature absorption databases, an entirely new approach to absorption spectroscopy (modified free induction decay spectroscopy), and unique experiment/computation fusion approaches and data processing techniques.  We developed a new thermal systems capstone course at the University of Colorado by leveraging the NSF CAREER resources to bring in $63k of additional funding for the class experiments.  We also spun off a workshop for high school students to experience firsthand what energy career paths are available through engineering.

In total, this award has directly supported a new hands-on laboratory course, 5 PhD theses, 16 journal publications, 1 patent, 2 plenary conference talks, 22 invited conference talks and seminars, 24 additional conference talks, and 8 poster presentations.
